title: I'm tired
body: I’ve been part of this fandom for about a year since I read the books, I’ve kind of passively consumed the show too but not watched it and…  I love every female character…  ALL OF THEM,  I LOVE SANSA I LOVE ARYA I LOVE DANY I LOVE THE DORNISH GIRLS AND THE HIGH GARDEN GIRLS AND EVEN CERSEI so can people stop telling me I hate Sansa because I’m a Dany fan or I hate Dany because I’m a Sansa fan, it’s possible to like more than one character and it’s not fucking healthy too define yourself by one character or ship and violently lash out at others

reblog.comment: I’ve been part of this fandom for about a year since I read the books, I’ve kind of passively consumed the show too but not watched it and…  I love every female character…  ALL OF THEM,  I LOVE SANSA I LOVE ARYA I LOVE DANY I LOVE THE DORNISH GIRLS AND THE HIGH GARDEN GIRLS AND EVEN CERSEI so can people stop telling me I hate Sansa because I’m a Dany fan or I hate Dany because I’m a Sansa fan, it’s possible to like more than one character and it’s not fucking healthy too define yourself by one character or ship and violently lash out at others

summary:
Daenerys was born during the greatest storm that has passed through Westeros, that’s why she’s referred to as Stormborn. 
The...
body:
Daenerys was born during the greatest storm that has passed through Westeros, that’s why she’s referred to as Stormborn.

The Night King and his army are referred to by Jon a storm.

So, what’s the connection? Because I don’t think these two things are a coincidence.

reblog.comment:

So, what’s the connection? Because I don’t think these two things are a coincidence.

So, what’s the connection? Because I don’t think these two things are a coincidence.

blog.name: argentvive
blog.title: argentvive
blog.description: Finding alchemy clues in literature.  Game of Thrones, Harry Potter, Lord of the Rings, His Dark Materials/The Book of Dust, The Wizard of Oz, a little Shakespeare

summary: GOT is All About Jon and Dany
title: GOT is All About Jon and Dany
body:
@geekyfeminist-love wrote:  I noticed, and wrote about, how on my recent rewatch Jon unconsciously tries to move closer to Dany at their first meeting, and when he’s stopped, she goes to meet him, treating him as her equal (perhaps in spite of herself).   I totally missed the detail of them standing in a Targaryen sigil.

This is a comment on my most recent post.  I haven’t been able to figure out how to reblog my really old posts, so here is “GOT Is All About Jon and Dany” again.  I wrote this based only on the show–I hadn’t read any of the books at this point.

———————————-

GRRM’s story is based on the structure and symbolism of alchemy.  This emblem, from Michael Maier’s Atalanta fugiens (1618), lays out the process.  

The alchemist, at left, puts the man and woman, the Principles of the Work, into a circle (the microcosm). He converts the circle into a square (the man and woman represents the four elements:  Male = Sulphur = fire and air; Female = Mercury = earth and water). He then converts the square into a triangle, which represents body, spirit, and soul.  Finally the whole is converted into a larger circle, the macrocosmic sphere which is the Philosopher’s Stone. The alchemist connects the two circles with the points of his compass.

When Jon and Dany first meet at Dragonstone, she is sitting on her throne and Jon approaches but stops well short of the stairs leading to the throne platform.  In fact, though you can’t see it here, he stops almost in the middle of the circular seal on the floor.  Dany descends from the throne and JOINS HIM within the circle (shortly after this particular image).  So already we have the two essential characters coming together within the initial circle.

The other essential character is the alchemist.  So who plays this role in GOT?  Well, she tells us that herself.  “I have brought Fire and Ice together,” Melisandre states in Season 7.  An interesting choice, since we know from earlier seasons that Melisandre has been wrong about a lot of things and has hardly been a benign figure, given her role in the deaths of Renly and Shireen.  But the alchemist in a story isn’t always a friendly old wizard like Gandalf or Dumbledore; in Faust, after all, it’s Mephistopheles–the Devil.  Melisandre is quite the all-purpose character.  She plays the role of Temptress, so Jon Snow can show his mettle and do the “Rejecting the Temptress” stage in the Hero’s Journey.  And of course she later resurrects him.  So her magic is real, just unreliable.

@geekyfeminist-love wrote:  I noticed, and wrote about, how on my recent rewatch Jon unconsciously tries to move closer to Dany at their first meeting, and when he’s stopped, she goes to meet him, treating him as her equal (perhaps in spite of herself).   I totally missed the detail of them standing in a Targaryen sigil.

summary: Iain Gleen thinks that Jon deserves Dany. As we know that Iain adores Dany we can absolutely thinks that Political Jon   theory...
body:
Iain Gleen thinks that Jon deserves Dany. As we know that Iain adores Dany we can absolutely thinks that Political Jon theory and Jon’s betrayal is absolutely nonsense and over.

But of course we are absolutely sure that delusional sick people continues their madnes and idiotism.

blog.name: jackoshadows
blog.title: Jak O' the Shadows
blog.description: I’m not going to swear an oath I can’t uphold. Talk about my father if you want. Tell me that’s the attitude that got him killed. But when enough people make false promises, words stop meaning anything. Then there are no more answers - only better and better lies. And lies won’t help us in this fight - Jon Snow.
